abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Verheij syndrome [VRJS; OMIM 615583] is a rare autosomal dominant neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by distinct clinical features, including growth retardation, intellectual disability, cardiac, and renal anomalies. VRJS is caused by deletions of chromosome 8q24.3 or pathogenic variants in the <jats:italic>PUF60</jats:italic> gene. Recently, pathogenic <jats:italic>PUF60</jats:italic> variants have been reported in some individuals with VRJS, contributing to the variability in the clinical presentation and severity of the condition. <jats:italic>PUF60</jats:italic> encodes a protein involved in regulating gene expression and cellular growth. In this report, we describe a new case of VRJS with developmental delay, cardiac-, and renal abnormalities, caused by a heterozygous pathogenic <jats:italic>PUF60</jats:italic> variant. Surprisingly, DNA methylation analysis revealed a pattern resembling the Cornelia de Lange syndrome (CdLS) episignature, suggesting a potential connection between <jats:italic>PUF60</jats:italic> and CdLS-related genes. This case report further delineates the clinical and molecular spectrum of VRJS and supports further research to validate the interaction between VRJS and CdLS.</jats:p>
